Lines 175-180.</ref> | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | frequently_updated = no | latest_release_version = 2.0beta2 | latest_release_date = {{Start date and age|1997|11|14|df=yes}}<ref name="FreeBSD">{{cite web |title=Index of /pub/FreeBSD/ports/distfiles/ |url=http://ftp.freebsd.org/pub/FreeBSD/ports/distfiles/ |work=FreeBSD project download server |publisher=The FreeBSD Project |accessdate=20 January 2012 |quote=xmove.2.0beta2.tar.gz    1997-Nov-14 01:05:34    624.2K    application/x-gzip}}.</ref> | discontinued = yes | status = Unmaintained | programming language = [[C (programming language)|C]] | operating_system = [[X Window System]] | genre = [[Terminal multiplexer]] | license = [[MIT License|MIT]]/X Consortium License<ref>[http://snapshot.debian.net/archive/2005/09/26/debian/pool/main/x/xmove/xmove_2.0beta2.orig.tar.gz Package sources]</ref> | website = None }} '''xmove''' is a [[computer program]] that allows the movement of [[X Window System]] applications between different displays and the persistence of X applications across [[X server]] restarts.<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.cs.columbia.edu/mcl/papers/xmove.ps.gz | format = [[gzip]]ped [[PostScript]] | archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/19970724010922/http://www.cs.columbia.edu/mcl/papers/xmove.ps.gz | archivedate = 1997-07-24 | first1 = Ethan | last1 = Solomita | first2 = James | last2 = Kempf | first3 = Dan | last3 = Duchamp | year = 1994 | title = XMOVE: A pseudoserver for X window movement | id = {{citeseerx|10.1.1.30.589}} }}</ref> It solves a problem in the design of X, where an X client (an X application) is tied to the X server (X display) it was started on for its lifetime. Also, if the X server is shut down, the client application is forced to stop running. xmove lets the client disconnect from its current X server, and connect to a new one, at any time. The transition is completely transparent to the client. xmove works by acting as a [[Proxy server|proxy]] between the client and server. It is a "pseudoserver" which stores enough server state so that clients can connect to a new server without being disrupted. == See also == * [[xpra]] — a more recent tool which is similar to xmove * [[guievict]] — a system for checkpointing and migrating the GUI of an X window application * the [[lbxproxy]] tool, which allows disconnecting and reconnecting == References == <references /> == External links == * [http://markballew.com/projects/xmove/ Xmove, IMproved (XIMove)] — by Mark C.
